questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: The image illustrated below represents the shape of congenital renal anomaly seen in a 10-year-old child. Radiological investigations indicate that both the renal units are low lying. Which of the following arteries most likely prevents the ascent of the kidney in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image shows horseshoe kidney. Inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys.

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of lower poles of the kidney. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux,obstruction and stone formation.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor (4 times more common in children with horseshoe kidneys than in the general population)
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows transillumination. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. The most probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Spermatocele.

Points in favor: If one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling then the swelling is not a hydrocele but maybe a cyst of the epididymis or spermatocele. Transillumination is present. The barley water appearance of the fluid is seen in spermatocele due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular, bunch of grapes

Present at the epididymal head,

Above and behind upper pole of testes

 Posterior to testis
Transillumination+

Transillumination+

(Chinese lantern pattern)
Barley water fluid appearance Crystal clear fluid
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision

questions.text: An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize the patient during his surgery postings. What is the size of the catheter used by the intern?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foleys catheter having a red coloured ring in the ballon port, indicating its size to be 18 F.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid except _______
questions.solution:
A high hematocrit (not low) is an indicator of hypoperfusion.

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour.

  • If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%.
  • If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include,

  1. Restlessness with tachycardia,
  2. Cool peripheries and
  3. High hematocrit

questions.text: What is the recommended margin for wide local excision in a patient with melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.8 mm. ?
questions.solution:
Resection margin of 1 cm is recommended for melanoma invading to a depth of 0.8mm.

Recommended margins of wide local excision:

Thickness Margin
In situ 0.5 cm
<1 mm 1 cm
1-2 mm 1-2 cm
>2-4 mm 2 cm
>4 mm 2 cm

questions.text: The following appearance on ERCP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The given appearance on ERCP is characteristic of Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). 

Mucin can be seen extruding from the ampulla of Vater, a so-called fish-eye lesion that is virtually diagnostic of IPMN.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, who presented with a thyroid nodule was advised to undergo FNAC. The cytology report classifies the nodule as Bethesda category 4. What would be the usual management in this case?
questions.solution:
The usual management of a patient classified as Bethesda category 4 is Lobectomy. 

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the thyroid is the initial screening test for thyroid nodules. The Bethesda system classifies thyroid FNAC into six categories. Each category is linked to a malignancy risk and has a recommended clinical management. 

Bethesda criteria for reporting thyroid cytopathology:

Category  Description Usual management
I Nondiagnostic or unsatisfactory Repeat FNA with image guidance
II Benign Clinical follow-up
III Atypia of undetermined significance/follicular lesion of undetermined significance Repeat FNA or lobectomy
IV Follicular neoplasm or suspicious for follicular neoplasm  Lobectomy
V Suspicious for malignancy  Lobectomy or total thyroidectomy
VI Malignant  Total thyroidectomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who presented with a painless lump in the breast following an injury was diagnosed with traumatic fat necrosis. All of the following features are present in this condition except:

choices.text: Lump is freely mobile in breast

questions.solution:
Lump in traumatic fat necrosis is fixed or tethered to the skin.

Traumatic fat necrosis mimics breast carcinoma. As it may present with:

  • Skin tethering
  • Nipple retraction
  • Lump in the breast(often painless).
  • Mammographic densities or calcifications

Note: A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump and biopsy is required for diagnosis.

It has no malignant potential.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent iron deficiency anemia and GI endoscopy reveals the dilated venules as shown in the below image. what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of endoscopy shows dilated venules appearing as linear red streaks converging on the antrum in longitudinal fashion, giving ‘Watermelon appearance of stomach’ which is characteristic of Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia.

GAVE :

  • Presence of both inflammatory and vascular components in mucosa.
  • Dilated mucosal blood vessels
  • Affects antrum of stomach
  • On endoscopy – Prominent longitudinal folds with parallel striking red stripes

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and indolent growth pattern.

  • It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.
  • The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid.
  • The tubular type has the best prognosis and solid has the worst.
  • Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: The most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction is ________
questions.solution:
The most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction is gastric cancer.

The two common causes of gastric outlet obstruction are gastric carcinoma and peptic ulcer disease (which leads to pyloric stenosis).

Gastric outlet obstruction should be considered malignant until proven otherwise.

Other causes of gastric outlet obstruction :

  • Pyloric mucosal diaphragm - It is rare and becomes apparent around middle life. Management is done by simple excision of the mucosal diaphragm.
  • Adult pyloric stenosis - It is a rare condition where patients have a long history of problems with gastric emptying. It is commonly treated by pyloroplasty.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed bleeding esophageal varices.  You resuscitate him with IV fluids followed by esophageal balloon tamponade with a Sengstaken–Blakemore tube. To prevent necrosis of the area in contact, you will decompress the tube every _______
questions.solution:
Sengstaken–Blakemore tube should be decompressed every 12 hours to prevent necrosis.

It is a device that is inserted through the nose or mouth and was used in the management of upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage due to esophageal varices.

There are three types of tubes used in controlling the upper GI bleed, which includes:

  • The Sengstaken–Blakemore tube has three ports- NG suction, oesophageal balloon, and gastric balloon.
  • The Minnesota tube has four ports at the end (one extra port for aspirating stuff from above the oesophageal balloon)
  • The Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single 500-600ml gastric balloon.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD with a constellation of features like impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of the femoral pulses. These features are seen in __________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome.

Leriche syndrome is a rare form of aorto-iliac Occlusive Disease (AIOD) which presents with a triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses. Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery will cause claudication of the buttock or thigh. Associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen because the calf is the most distal large muscle group and is used extensively in walking.

The other options correspond to sound alike signs/syndromes.

Option A: Leigh syndrome: is an inherited neurodegenerative condition. It usually becomes apparent in infancy, often after a viral infection. Early symptoms may include poor sucking ability; loss of head control and motor skills; loss of appetite; vomiting; and seizures. As the condition progresses, symptoms may include weakness and lack of muscle tone, spasticity, movement disorders, cerebellar ataxia and peripheral neuropathy.

Option B: Lhermitte's sign: Shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.

Option C: Lemierre’s syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis in the internal jugular vein. This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of an oropharyngeal infection. The organism is typically a fusiform bacillus. Presents with severe neck pain, septicemia, or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with infection in the upper aerodigestive tract.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with the c/o abdominal pain, fever, malaise, anorexia, and nausea . He was kept on intravenous fluids for 12 hours. The next day he appears anxious with a drawn face,  sunken eyes, dry tongue and has a  thready (irregular) pulse. The extremities are cold and clammy, the abdomen is rigid and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. What can be the most likely cause of this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features describe a typical patient of unresolved Late or terminal generalised peritonitis. The characteristic appearance given has been called "Hippocratic facies" - drawn and anxious face of the patient.

The abdomen shows generalised rigidity. Distension is common and bowel sounds are absent. Circulatory failure occurs, with cold, clammy extremities, sunken eyes, dry tongue, thready (irregular) pulse, and drawn and anxious face (known as hippocratic facies). The patient finally lapses into unconsciousness.

In early diffuse peritonitis,

  • Tenderness and generalised guarding are found on palpation (no rigidity)
  • Infrequent bowel sounds may still be heard for a few hours.
  • Pulse and temperature rise in accord with degree of inflammation and infection.

questions.text: A child born to a 38-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, protruding tongue, and a 'Simian crease' on the palm. Karyotyping revealed trisomy of chromosome 21. Which of the following anomalies will you most likely see in this child?
questions.solution:
Annular pancreas is more prevalent in children with Down syndrome as given in the scenario above. It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia.

It occurs because of the failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum. Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.

Treatment is duodenoduodenostomy.

Pancreas divisum: When the dorsal and ventral ducts fail to fuse during embryogenesis, it leads to pancreas divisum. As most pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, pancreas divisum can lead to partial obstruction caused by a small minor papilla, leading to chronic backpressure in the duct. This relative outflow obstruction can lead to relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis. The incidence of pancreas divisum in the general population is about 10%.

questions.text: A surgeon needs broader access to the pelvic cavity and he decides to make a long, transverse incision as shown in the image. This incision is known as ______
questions.solution:
Maylard incision is shown in the above image. It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. The Maylard incision is also called the Mackenrodt incision.

Pfannenstiel incision is the lower transverse incision made in the lower segment of the uterus below the umbilicus and just above the pubic symphysis. It is commonly used in the Caesarian section and for abdominal hysterectomy.

McEvedy's incision was a lateral paramedian incision which used to incise the rectus sheath along its lateral margin. It had a very high incisional hernia rate.

Lanz incision is a variation of the traditional Mc Burney's incision and is used to perform an open appendectomy. It is made at the Mc Burney's point along the transverse plane and is cosmetically better. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision which follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and the adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with fever, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort. CBC shows leukocytosis but there is no tenderness, rigidity, or guarding elicited by per abdominal examination. The case is diagnosed as silent appendicitis after an abdominal ultrasound. This condition is usually seen when the appendix is in    ________
questions.solution:
Silent appendicitis occurs when the appendix is in the retrocaecal position. 

In retrocaecal appendicitis, it is difficult to elicit tenderness on palpation in the right iliac region. Even deep pressure in the right lower quadrant may fail to elicit tenderness the reason being that the caecum, distended with gas, prevents the pressure exerted by the palpating hand from reaching the inflamed appendix, so it has been called as 'silent appendicitis'

Various positions of appendix is shown in the below image

questions.text: A gastric ulcer is in the region of the stomach marked in the image below. What will be the type of ulcer in this case according to the Modified Johnson anatomical classification?
questions.solution:
The above image shows type IV of the modified johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer. It is seen high along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is not related to increased gastric acid levels.

Modified johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer:

Type Location Acid level
I Lesser curve at incisura Low to normal
II Gastric body with duodenal ulcer Increased
III Prepyloric Increased
IV High on lesser curve Normal
V Anywhere Normal , NSAID induced

Modified johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer:

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts subcuticular sutures.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either absorbable or non-absorbable suture material may be used.

There are four frequently used suture techniques.

Interrupted:  the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and then passed through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at the right angle.

The distance from the entry point of the needle to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured, and each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart (2x).

 

Continuous: The first suture is placed in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound.

 

Mattress: Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal and are used for the eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

The initial suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture, but then the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound.

questions.text: A soldier presents to a referral hospital one day after sustaining a high-velocity shrapnel injury to his right thigh. There is an irregular entry wound at the site of injury and he complains of severe pain at the wound site. On examination, crepitus is present along with a thin, brown, sweet-smelling discharge from the wound site and the pain severity has increased. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is Gas gangrene/ Clostridial myonecrosis, which is caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Military wounds provide an ideal environment for gas gangrene as the kinetic energy of high-velocity missiles or shrapnel causes extensive tissue damage. Patients who are immunocompromised, diabetic, or have malignant disease are also at greater risk. The usual incubation period is <24 hours of injury.

Gas gangrene wound infections are associated with severe local wound pain and crepitus (gas in the tissues). The wound produces a thin, brown, sweet-smelling exudate, in which Gram staining will reveal bacteria. Edema and spreading gangrene occur due to the release of collagenase, hyaluronidase, other proteases, and alpha-toxin. Early systemic complications like circulatory collapse and organ failure can occur without adequate treatment.

Management includes high doses of intravenous penicillin and aggressive debridement of affected tissues. Amputations should be performed under antibiotic prophylaxis.

Synergistic spreading gangrene (also called as subdermal gangrene or necrotizing fasciitis) is not caused by clostridia. Multiple organisms are responsible like coliforms, staphylococci, Bacteroides spp., anaerobic streptococci, and peptostreptococci acting in synergy. The aerobic bacteria destroy the living tissue, allowing bacteria to thrive.

Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney’s synergistic gangrene and scrotal infections as Fournier’s gangrene are such examples.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with fever, haematuria, and flank pain. Her X-ray KUB is shown below. The condition seen affecting the left kidney in the X-Ray is usually associated with all of the following infections except ______
questions.solution:
The image depicts X-ray KUB showing staghorn calculus formed from a struvite (magnesium-ammonium-phosphate) stone which can be associated with Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus infections. E. coli infection never cause struvite stones.

Struvite stones (triple phosphate stones)  are usually seen in a setting of infection with urease-producing bacteria like proteus, pseudomonas, and staphylococcus. They can grow very large and form a cast of the renal pelvis and calyces resulting in staghorn calculi. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of struvite stones.

questions.text: Which of the following  suture materials elicits the highest tissue reaction among the options given below?
questions.solution:
Plain catgut shows the highest tissue reaction in the given options above.

It is made of collagen derived from healthy sheep or cattle. 

It is absorbed by Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7–10 days.

Plain catgut is used to ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas, and other tissues that heal rapidly. The tensile strength is lost within 7–10 days and shows marked patient variability.

Contraindications: Not for use in tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support
Synthetic absorbable sutures are superior in this case.

Chromic catgut is tanned with chromium salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue.

questions.text: A plastic surgeon uses a Wolfe graft to cover a smaller area of skin defect. All of the following are true regarding these grafts except:
questions.solution:
Wolfes graft is a type of full-thickness graft. The best cosmetic appearance is seen with a full-thickness graft.

Full-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and the complete layer of the dermis. They are used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin is required.

Full-thickness grafts are associated with,

  • The greatest amount of primary contraction,
  • The least amount of secondary contraction,
  • The highest durability, and
  • The best cosmetic appearance.

As a result, they are frequently used in reconstructing superficial wounds of the face and the hands.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: Identify the following surgical landmark denoted in green.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Triangle of Hesselbach which is surgical landmark in hernia surgery.

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle are:

  • Laterally by Inferior epigastric artery
  • Medially by lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by inguinal ligament

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A young male patient, with a history of blunt abdominal trauma, was brought to the ER. As he was hemodynamically unstable, and FAST examination revealed free fluid, an immediate laparotomy was done. Since severe bleeding from the liver was present, the following manoeuvre was done to visualize the injury but, the bleeding continued even after clamping. What could be the probable source of bleeding in this case?

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in Pringle maneuver and bleeding from hepatic vein will continue even after clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament.

Pringle maneuver:

  • When severe bleeding from the liver is present, the Pringle maneuver is a valuable adjunct to slow blood flow enough to visualize the injury.
  • The hepatoduodenal ligament is encircled with a vessel loop or vascular clamp to occlude hepatic blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein.
  • This maneuver helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding, which will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped.
  • In many cases, the liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.
  • Hepatic parenchyma that appears to be devitalized should be debrided and drains should be placed when injuries appear to be at risk for a bile leak.
  • A vascularized pedicle of the omentum may reduce parenchymal bleeding and promote healing of the laceration when it is packed with the liver injury.

questions.text: What is the size of the surgical blade shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
The 22-blade is shown in the image and is often used for abdominal incisions.

The 11-blade is often used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy.

The 15-blade is often used for minor surgical procedures.

questions.text: What will be the management plan in a patient BIRADS grade 2?
questions.solution:
The management plan in this patient would be to undergo Routine annual screening.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 2 means that it is a benign lesion and for these patients, annual screening is advised.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: You are a medical officer at the blood bank and receive several units of packed RBCs, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate following a blood donation camp. Which among the following components would you want to use at the earliest?
questions.solution:
Platelets have a shelf life of only 5 days and hence they have to be used at the earliest.

They are usually stored on a special agitator at 20–24 °C. They are given to the patients with thrombocytopenia or with platelet dysfunction who are bleeding or undergoing surgery.

Other options:

Packed cells (PRBCs) (option A) are stored in a SAG-M solution (saline–adenine–glucose–mannitol) and has a shelf life of 5 weeks at 2–6 °C. (Older storage regimens included storage in CPD – citrate–phosphate–dextrose solutions which have a shelf life of 2–3 weeks).

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) (option B), is stored at −40 to −50°C, while the cryoprecipitate (option C) is stored at -30°C, and both have a shelf life of two years.

NOTE:

According to UKBTS Red Book guidelines, shelf life of PRBCs in SAG-M solution is 35days (5 weeks), whereas Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition says that shelf life of PRBC in additive solution is 35-42 days.

questions.text: What is the pressure used in Vacuum-assisted closure for wounds?
questions.solution:
• The pressure used in vacuum assisted closure for wound healing is –125 mm Hg.
  • Applying negative pressure appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and Ulcers.
  • It acts by decreasing edema, by removing interstitial fluid and as a result helps in decreasing bacterial counts and cell proliferation increases.

questions.text: Management of grade 2 splenic injury with no active bleeding in an 8-year-old child is _____.
questions.solution:
Conservative management is usually followed in a stable patient with no active bleeding, younger than 55 years of age, and with grade I,II,III injuries.

Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, active bleeding, and grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

                           AAST Spleen Injury Scale
INJURY GRADE INJURY TYPE DESCRIPTION OF INJURY
I

Hamatoma

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block.

Causes of AV block:

Autonomic:

  • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity

Metabolic:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency

Drug related:

  • Beta blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Adenosine
  • Digitalis
  • Lithium
  • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics

Infections:

  • Endocarditis
  • Lyme disease
  • Chaga's disease
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diphtheria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Inflammatory:

  • SLE
  • RA
  • Scleroderma

Infiltrative:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemachromatosis

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with _______.
questions.solution:
Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C infection.

Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate when the temperature is less than 37°C. Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins in the serum. Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. 

Important conditions associated with cryoglobulinemia:

  • Hepatitis C
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Connective tissue disorders

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity?
questions.solution:
Insulin levels are increased in obesity.

  • It stimulates the synthesis of fatty acids and TAG, and decreases the rate of lipolysis.
  • Thyroxine, growth hormone and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence their levels are reduced in obesity.
  • Hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance are pervasive features of obesity.

Insulin resistance is more strongly linked to intraabdominal fat than to fat in other depots.

Major factors of insulin resistance in obesity:

  • Insulin itself, by inducing receptor downregulation
  • Increased FFA and capable of impairing insulin action
  • Intracellular lipid accumulation
  • Circulating peptides produced by adipocytes, e.g., TNF-α, IL-6, RBP4 and resistin modifying insulin action.

questions.text: The presence of serpiginous ulcers on esophageal endoscopy indicates ______
questions.solution:
CMV lesions appear as serpiginous ulcers in an otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

questions.text: Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with all of the following except
questions.solution:
Antiphospholipid syndrome is not associated with hemorrhage. 

It is an autoantibody-mediated disorder characterized by arterial thrombosis, venous thrombosis, and recurrent fetal loss. These autoantibodies bind to the phospholipids present on the endothelial cells and activate coagulation and thrombosis formation.

Important manifestations of venous thrombosis are:

  • Deep vein thrombosis of legs
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis.

Important manifestations of arterial thrombosis are:

  • Stroke, transient ischemic attacks
  • Retinal artery thrombosis
  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis- due to the vegetations formed by platelet fibrin microthrombi
  • Leg ulcers, gangrene of the digits.

Important obstetric manifestations are

  • Preeclampsia
  • Recurrent fetal loss
  • Premature birth.

questions.text: All the following are features of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia except

choices.text: Restrictive changes in pulmonary function test

questions.solution:
•  Males are predominantly affected (4:1) in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical Pulmonary eosinophilia:

  • It is seen in persons infected with lymph node dwelling filarial species
  • Males are predominantly affected (4:1)
  • Nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough
  • Weight loss, low grade fever, adenopathy
  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities, increased bronchovascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titres
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in lungs and hence not found in blood
  • Treatment: Diethyl carbamazine

questions.text: Most common type of Multiple Sclerosis
questions.solution:
The most common type of MS is the relapsing type [RMS] (~90%)

About 2% of RMS progresses to secondary progressive MS [SPMS] and about 10% develop the type of primary progressive MS [PPMS]

Note: SPMS or even PPMS will occasionally experience relapses and remissions, although far less often than in RMS. The term progression is now reserved to describe neurological worsening that accumulates independently from disease activity.

Multiple sclerosis:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by multiple episodes of neurological deficits due to patchy white matter lesions that involve various sites of the brain. It is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath.

The demyelinated plaques are the hallmark of MS

questions.text: A boy presents with breathlessness to the hospital. He gives a history of leg pain over the calf for few days for which he sought massaging by his mother after which he developed breathlessness. Which of the following findings on the ECG would suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism for this patient?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis leading to pulmonary embolism.

The specific abnormality in ECG seen in pulmonary embolism is

The S1 Q3 T3 sign:

  • S wave in lead I
  • Q wave in lead III
  • An inverted T wave in lead III

Related Pearl: Risk factors for venous thromboembolism

Patient factors:

  • Age
  • Obesity
  • Varicose veins
  • Immobility
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium
  • High-dose estrogen therapy
  • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Thrombophilia

  • Congenital
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant
    • Factor V leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance
    • Dysfibrinogenaemias
  • Acquired
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant

Disease or surgical procedure

  • Trauma or surgery, especially of pelvis, hip, and lower limb
  • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic
  • Heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Paralysis of lower limb(s) infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Polycythaemia
  • Paraproteinaemia
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Homocysteinemia

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement with regard to this scenario?

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.solution:
Transient loss of consciousness is suggestive of syncope. As this was the first episode, the initial evaluation would include:

  • History
  • Physical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to rule out orthostatic hypotension.
  • A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia

Other options:

Option b: If the ECG is normal, no further tests are needed. If the ECG is suggestive of cardiac arrhythmia, then further tests including continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiological studies may be done.

Option c: Tilt-table testing is done in patients with recurrent syncopal attacks who are suspected to have vasovagal syncope. Psychiatric evaluation is done in patients with recurrent unexplained syncopal attacks.

Option d: Vestibular neuritis is associated with vertigo, where, the patients typically complain of dizziness and a sense of spinning of the head.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination, there are soft heart sounds, JVP is increased, and an inspiratory decline in systolic blood pressure of 14 mmHg is observed. Which of the following statements about the condition is true?
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old male patient with acute breathlessness, falling BP, rising JVP, and soft heart sounds suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. In a cardiac tamponade, the ECG findings are low voltage and electrical alternans.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intrapericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

  • Option A: Kussmaul sign is a rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration.It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.
  • Option C: y descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of limited or absent late diastolic filling of ventricle. Prominent x and y descent is seen in constrictive pericarditis.
  • Option D: The diastolic dip-and-plateau pattern, also known as a square root sign, is produced when early rapid diastolic inflow into the ventricle commences but is then abruptly halted by an opposing force. It is not seen in the cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A sewer worker presents with high-grade fever, neck rigidity, and signs of meningismus. Laboratory findings are suggestive of renal failure and elevated liver enzymes. The most appropriate drug to be prescribed in this case is _________.
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of leptospirosis. Hence, the drug to be prescribed in this case is penicillin.

Following points are in favor of leptospirosis:

  • A sewer (an underground conduit for carrying off drainage water and waste matter) worker 
  • Signs of meningismus
  • Laboratory diagnosis of renal failure and elevated liver enzymes (Weil’s disease)

Leptospirosis:

  • is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism.
  • It is a zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species, rats are well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. Clinical distinction between 2 phases may not be seen.

  • Acute leptospiremic phase-organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase-organism can be cultured from urine.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic but a few may present with severe manifestations(Weil's disease-triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury).
  • Clinical features include high grade fever, liver and kidney impairment, and hemorrhages(GI, pulmonary(M/C), petechiae and purpura).

Treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete comes for a routine examination. He has no symptoms. The ECG is as shown below. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 45 bpm. The patient is an athlete and heart rates are usually lower in athletes.

As the patient is asymptomatic no further therapy should be given to increase the heart rate.

Sinus bradycardia:

  • Sinus bradycardia is defined as SA nodal rhythm with a rate <60 beats/min. However, in young healthy adults and athletes, a resting heart rate of <60 beats/min is common.
  • Also, a sinus pause of upto 3 seconds on ECG is commonly seen in athletes and elderly individuals.
  • If the rate is <40 beats/min, in an awake individual in the absence of physical training, then it is considered abnormal.

Diagnosis of SA node dysfunction:

  • The presence of abnormal sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is insufficient to diagnose SA node dysfunction. Longer-term electrocardiographic recording and clinical correlation are required to establish the diagnosis.
  • On the contrary, the presence of symptoms without any sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is sufficient to rule out SA node dysfunction.

questions.text: A 20-year old male came to the hospital with complaints of cough and difficulty in breathing and swelling of the face. On physical examination dilated neck veins were seen. A clinical diagnosis of SVC syndrome was made. Chest X-ray revealed widening of the superior mediastinum. What is the next step?

choices.text: Diuretics with low salt diet, head elevation, oxygen

questions.solution:
The next step in the above case is to obtain a CT scan. SVC syndrome is diagnosed by the absence or reduced opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.

Superior vena cava syndrome: It is a clinical manifestation due to the obstruction of superior vena cava which results in reduced venous return from head and neck and upper extremities.

Causes:

  1. Intravascular devices such as central venous catheters and pacemaker or defibrillator lead.
  2. Malignant tumors:
  • Lung cancer (MC: small-cell and squamous cell histologies)
  • Lymphoma (MC cause of SVC syndrome in young adults)

3. Metastatic cancers to mediastinal lymph nodes, from testicular and breast carcinoma

4. Other causes: Benign tumors, aortic aneurysm, thyromegaly, thrombosis, and fibrosing mediastinitis from prior irradiation, histoplasmosis, or Behçet’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Swelling of neck and face (commonly around the eyes)
  • Cough, dyspnea, dysphagia
  • Nasal congestion, Epistaxis, Hemoptysis
  • Headache, pain, dizziness, syncope, lethargy

Symptoms are aggravated on bending forward or lying down.

Physical findings:

  • Dilated neck veins, increased collateral veins on the anterior chest wall, cyanosis.
  • Edema of face, arms, chest
  • In severe cases, proptosis and edema of tongue and larynx may be seen.
  • Bilateral breast edema (unilateral edema is seen in axillary or subclavian vein obstruction).
  • Esophageal varices may be seen in SVC syndrome caused by hemodialysis catheters. Depending on the position of esophageal varices, the site of SVC obstruction can be evaluated as below:
    • Varices in upper third of esophagus - due to obstruction of SVC proximal to azygous vein
    • Varices in the entire length of esophagus - due to obstruction of SVC distal to azygous vein

Diagnosis:

  • SVC syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically.
  • Chest X-ray shows the widening of the superior mediastinum.
  • A CT scan is done for a detailed study of the mediastinal anatomy. SVC syndrome is diagnosed by the absence or reduce opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.
  • Once the CT report is obtained, further management depends on whether the patient has cancer or not.
    • If there is no history of malignancy: Detailed workup is done to rule out benign causes
    • If the patient has a known malignancy: Proceed to treatment

Treatment:

  • Management includes relieving tracheal obstruction if present and reduction of the swelling.
  • Diuretics with low-salt diet, head elevation and oxygen provide symptomatic relief.
  • Radiotherapy is provided for non-small-cell lung cancer, other metastatic solid tumors.
  • Chemotherapy is provided for small-cell carcinoma of the lung, lymphoma, or germ cell tumor.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Fluent aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side with difficulty in walking, dysphagia, and dysarthria. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome).

In the given case scenario, there is contralateral hemisensory loss of pain and temperature, with ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome and sensory loss on face associated with dysphagia and dysarthria which are characteristic of this condition.

Note: Lateral medullary (Wallenberg’s) syndrome is due to occlusion of the vertebral, posterior inferior cerebellar, superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

Structures affected on the ipsilateral side:

  • Fifth nerve nucleus and descending tract: Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over the face
  • Cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract: Ataxia
  • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating)
  • Ninth and Tenth nerve fibers: Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of the palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex.

Structures affected on the contralateral side:

  • Spinothalamic tract: Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face

questions.text: A 70-year-old obese male presents with bilateral knee pain worsening on exertion. On examination, a palpable nodule was found in the 2nd DIP joint in his right hand as shown below. The patient has no other complaints. What is the appropriate pharmacological method to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario presented the most probable diagnosis is osteoarthritis. The nodules palpable in the DIP are Heberden’s nodes. NSAIDs (like ibuprofen) followed by regular follow-up is the most appropriate way of managing the patient among the options provided.

Other options:

  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used in the treatment of gouty arthritis as a hypouricemic agent.
  • Secukinumab is an anti-IL-17A monoclonal antibody used for the management of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Intra-articular steroids are provided if the patient does not respond to Acetaminophen/NSAIDs, it is not the first-line treatment for osteoarthritis. Furthermore, its efficacy in the treatment of OA is controversial. Thus, the best option is NSAIDs.

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of the cirrhosis. 

Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman suffers from sudden onset of fever, headache, photophobia and is disoriented. CBC shows hemoglobin of  11.2 g/dl, platelet count of 32,000/uL. Peripheral smear of the patient is shown in the image. The serum creatinine is 3.9 mg/dl and BUN (blood urea nitrogen ) is 38 mg/dl. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this disease?

choices.text: Cause of the disease is ADAM TS-13 deficiency/defect
20% patients  will have falsely positive  RA factor
Mitomycin-C can also cause this disease
Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.solution:
Blood transfusion is not the mainstay of treatment in TTP.


The question describes the classical pentad of neurological features, fever, thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia and renal failure which is diagnostic of TTP(thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura). Blood transfusion is avoided because damage can occur because of IgM antibodies.

TTP: 

  • Deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves  multimers of VWF.
  • Persistence of the VWF molecules causes pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites leading to the classic pentad of TTP.
  • 20% patients will have falsely positive RA factor.
  • Mitomycin-C can also cause this disease(antitumor antibiotic that inhibits cell division, protein synthesis, and fibroblast proliferation).
Pentad of TTP Remarks
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia Due to mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet rich-microthrombi
Thrombocytopenia Due to deposition of platelets in microthrombi
Renal failure Due to deposition of microthrombi in the renal vasculature, increased serum creatinine.
Neurologic findings Headache, confusion, transient focal deficits
Fever  

TTP is a disease that is prone to, but does not always have microvascular thrombosis, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolysis, and organ dysfunction.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhoea,  weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension.  Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of celiac disease, and the single best investigation to diagnose the condition is IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies.

Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa, and malabsorption of nutrients. 

The typical symptoms include weight loss, chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The malabsorption of nutrients may cause the following conditions:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Bruising due to vitamin K deficiency
  • Bone pain due to osteomalacia
  • Hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency
  • Neurological signs like peripheral neuropathy and ataxia due to vitamin B12 deficiency

Pancreatic insufficiency

Faecal chymotrypsin
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)

Due to Enterobacter or Pseudomonas - jejunal aspirate >103 CFU

Due to other organisms - jejunal aspirate >105 CFU

questions.text: Following feature (Image A) is characteristic of a certain disease. On investigation, the lady was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern (Image B). Positivity of which of the given antibody would predict a higher risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A is a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma. Image B shows the nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and it represents antibodies to RNA). The pattern is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. Anti-scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at higher risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, scleroderma patients experience puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and Digital ulceration
  • Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma, have dysphagia, and GERD at the level of esophagus
  • Mask like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing and beak‐like nose.The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients .
  • Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti RNA polymerase III are seen in Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic sclerosis  which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstial lung disease.

Other options:

  • Anti centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
  • Anti U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.
  • Anti U3-RNP (Antifibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old  male with a h/o atopy presented to the casualty  with sudden onset breathlessness, and wheezing. He is able to speak only a few words and his pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is not a part of the mainstay of treatment in this case?

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added if response is not good to SABA

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of severe, acute attack of asthma. In an attack of acute severe asthma, sedatives should be never be given as they may depress ventilation. 

Management of acute attack of asthma:

  • A high concentration of oxygen should be given by face mask and oxygen saturation should be maintained at >90%.
  • The mainstay of treatment are high doses of SABA given either by nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer.
  • In severely ill patients with impending respiratory failure, IV β2-agonists may be given.
  • A nebulized anticholinergic may be added if there is not a good response to β2-agonists alone.
  • In patients who are refractory to inhaled therapies, a slow infusion of aminophylline can also be given.

Features of Acute severe attack of asthma include:

  • Inability to speak a complete sentence in one breath
  • Pulse >120/min
  • Respiratory rate >25/min
  • FEV1 between 33 to 50% of predicted
  • Pulsus paradoxus of >10 mmHg

Classification of severity of asthma exacerbations:

  MILD MODERATE SEVERE IMPENDING RESPIRATORY FAILURE
SYMPTOMS    
Breathlessness With activity With talking At rest At rest
Speech Sentences Phrases Words Mute
SIGNS

HEART RATE <100 100-120 >120 Relative bradycardia
Pulsus paradoxus <10 10-25 Often >25 Often absent

PaCo2(mm hg) <42 <42 >42 >42

questions.text: The following sign seen in pancreatitis is
questions.solution:
The image above shows bruising in the flanks. This sign is the Grey Turner’s sign seen in pancreatitis.

  • Cullen’s sign: Periumbilical bruising seen in pancreatitis
  • Aaron sign – In appendicitis, pressure over Mcburneys point elicits epigastric pain
  • Murphy’s sign-in inflammation of the gall bladder wall occurs; helps distinguish acute cholecystitis from biliary colic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent productive cough and clubbing. On auscultation, wheeze and crackles are present.  The signet ring sign is seen on HRCT. Which of the following statement is false for this condition?

choices.text: It has  a reversible airway dilation of the lungs
MAC bacterium complex affects the midlung fields
Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis involves central airways
Most common clinical presentation is a persistent productive cough

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis refers to an irreversible airway dilation that involves the lung in either a focal or a diffuse manner. 

It is caused by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue due to complications from infections, congenital conditions, or autoimmune disorders.

There are 4 morphological types:

  1. Tubular or cylindrical type
  2. Cystic type
  3. Varicose type
  4. Traction bronchiectasis - seen in interstitial lung disease and is associated with fibrosis

Clinically, they have a cough with excessive foul-smelling mucopurulent sputum, clubbing, crackles, and rhonchi.

Treatment of bronchiectasis

  • Antibiotic treatment targeting the causative pathogen (most common: H. influenzae and P. aeruginosa) should be administered for a minimum of 10–14 days.
  • NTM infection: a macrolide (clarithromycin and azithromycin) combined with rifampin and ethambutol.
  • Mucolytic administration: The mucolytic dornase (DNase) is recommended routinely in CF-related bronchiectasis, but not in non-CF bronchiectasis, given concerns about potential harm in the non-CF population.
  • Bronchial hygiene
  • Hydration
  • Aerosolization of bronchodilators.
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g., hypertonic saline).
  • Chest physiotherapy.
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation.
  • Refractory cases: Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation.

 

HRCT is the investigation of choice - most specific.

HRCT findings in bronchiectasis

  • The signet ring sign is seen when the dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery branch are seen in cross-section. The bronchus and artery should be the same size, whereas, in bronchiectasis, the bronchus is 1.5 times the size of the adjacent vessel.
  • Thickened secretions are seen as tree-in-bud pattern.
  • Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus. 
  • String of beads appearance is seen as alternate dilatation and constriction in varicose bronchiectasis. 
  • Cluster of grapes appearance is seen as cysts emanating from the bronchial wall in cystic bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT of the head is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp: 101 F, BP: 120/88 mmHg, PR: 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.
CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space. This is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.
SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Other options:

  1. IV Ceftriaxone: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.
  2. IV Tenecteplase: Used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.
  3. Aspirin: Used for acute ischemic stroke when fibrinolysis is contraindicated

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the anterior surface of lower legs, ankles, and thighs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Other options:

Pyoderma gangrenosum:

  • is a rare non‐infectious neutrophilic dermatosis commonly associated with underlying systemic diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Ulcerative pyoderma gangrenosum presents with small, tender, red blue papules, plaques, or pustules that evolve into painful ulcers with characteristic violaceous undermined edges.

 

Image: Pyoderma gangrenosum. Large purulent ulcer with violaceous undermined borders.

Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

questions.text: All the following are seen in the clinical condition depicted by the blood picture except _____.
questions.solution:
The above blood picture shows sickle cell anemia. Thrombocytopenia is not seen in sickle cell anemia.

Laboratory findings of sickle cell anemia

  • The peripheral blood smear:
    • Irreversibly sickled cells comprising 5–50% of red cells
    • Reticulocytosis (10–25%)
    • Nucleated red blood cells
    • Howell–Jolly bodies and target cells (Hyposplenism)
  • The white blood cell count - elevated to 12,000–15,000/mcL
  • Reactive thrombocytosis may occur.
  • Indirect bilirubin levels are high.

questions.text: Which among the following  conditions is most likely to produce the murmur depicted below?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. Ejection systolic murmur is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse- It is a slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. Carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • A double apical impulse may be recognised, and in the later stages, the apical impulse may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation:

  • In the early stages, early systolic ejection sound may be heard. It disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid.
  • As the stenosis worsens, the LV systole gets prolonged and there is delayed closure of the aortic valve. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, it might lead to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 sounds may be heard in severe cases, when the diastolic and systolic functions of the left ventricle have been reduced.
  • Murmur- The murmur in aortic stenosis is an ejection systolic murmur. This murmur starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. The murmur radiates to the neck and base of heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in all except
questions.solution:
Endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) is indicated in all of the above except acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess.

Endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection:

  • Meningitis
  • Subperiosteal abscess
  • Epidural abscess
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Any visual loss

 

Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in Chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, Allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma and Repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Tilley’s forceps. It is used for nasal packing, ear dressing, removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

Other options:

Options A and B: Walsham and Asch’s forceps are used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

Walsham forceps is mainly used to reduce bone fracture.

Asch’s forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

Option D: Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to atlantoaxial joint subluxation. It is associated with the overuse of diathermy either for the removal of the adenoid or following curettage when used for hemostasis. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on a CT scan. Holman-Miller sign is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the infratemporal fossa. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.solution:
The mass has spread into the infratemporal fossa, so its Stage 2C.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Modified sessions, et al)

I A: Limited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vault
I B: Extension into ≥ 1 sinus
II A: Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa
II B: Full occupation of the pterygopalatine fossa without erosion of orbital bones
II C: Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates
III A: Erosion of skull base-minimal intracranial
III B: Erosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

questions.text: Otosclerosis involves the _________ layer of otic capsule.
questions.solution:
Otosclerosis involves the enchondral layer of the otic capsule.

Within the enchondral layer, there are sometimes islands of unossified cartilage rests that give rise to otosclerosis.

The otic capsule is made of 3 layers:

  • Endosteal: Innermost
  • Enchondral: Middle layer derived from cartilage that ossifies
  • Periosteal: Outermost layer

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is newly diagnosed to have plaque psoriasis, with no associated features of psoriatic arthritis. The dermatologist has graded the disease to be moderate type, based on the Psoriasis area severity index (PASI). Which of the following can be instituted as first-line therapy to manage his condition?
questions.solution:
Phototherapy with narrowband UV-B is the recommended first-line therapy in this patient, as he has moderate psoriasis without arthritis.

Psoriasis Area Severity Index (PASI) is the grading of erythema, scaling and induration in different regions of the body and gives a combined score ranging from 0 to 72.

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy would have this most prominent histologic finding as marked with red arrows in the given image?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with red arrows in the given image is Grenz zone. It is most prominent in the case of lepromatous leprosy.

The Grenz zone is a narrow area of the papillary dermis uninvolved by the underlying pathology. The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy as there are scarce granulomas to fill this space.

Dermal tuberculoid granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are found in tuberculoid leprosy. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

This zone is also seen in Granuloma faciale, B cell lymphoma, and other diseases.

Image: Grenz Zone in Lepromatous Leprosy

questions.text: In a 20-year-old female who is suffering from chronic urticaria, you notice that the following three phenomenons occur in a sequential manner on stroking her skin. i) Redness in the line of stroke, ii) edema, and iii) Spread of redness around the line of stoke. These events are also associated with severe itching. What is this pattern of dermographism?
questions.solution:
The sequential occurrence of these events in a patient with urticaria, associated with itching is suggestive of symptomatic dermographism.

Dermographism is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

  • Simple dermographism is defined as the triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin.
  • However, in <5%, it is accompanied by severe itching (symptomatic dermographism or factitious urticaria).
  • Patients complain of whealing and itching at sites of trauma, friction with clothing or scratching the skin. The itching is usually disproportionately severe compared with whealing and is often most severe at night. 
  • The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the wheals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

Other forms of dermographism include

  • Red dermographism - repeated rubbing is necessary to induce small punctate wheals.
  • Cholinergic dermographism - seen in some patients with cholinergic urticaria. Here, the dermographic response consists of an erythematous line studded with punctate wheals.
  • Delayed dermographism - after normal fading of the triple response, a wheal returns in the same site, but is usually tender and persists for about 48 hours.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions showed IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae. The most probable diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis.

Dermatitis herpetiformis

  • Urticaria and grouped vesicles
  • Predominantly males, most often in the third and fourth decade
  • Association with intestinal celiac disease and responds to a gluten-free diet
  • Extremely pruritic plaques and vesicles 
  • Antibodies cross-react with reticulin, a component of the anchoring fibrils that tether the epidermal basement membrane to the superficial dermis.
  • The resultant injury and inflammation produce a subepidermal blister.
  • Fibrin and neutrophils accumulate selectively at the tips of dermal papillae, forming small microabscesses
  • True subepidermal blister
  • Direct immunofluorescence: Discontinuous, granular deposits of lgA that selectively localize in the tips of dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
