questions.text: Which of the following diseases is characterised by the given nail change?
questions.solution:
This image shows the most frequent nail change seen in lichen planus, an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate.

 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image : Trachonychia

questions.text: The image given below is a characteristic finding of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear drop bladder (pear shaped bladder) characteristically seen in pelvic lipomatosis, bilateral pelvic hematoma, pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Pear-shaped (or teardrop-shaped) bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed to resemble a pear. The pear may be inverted or upright, depending on how the excess pelvic tissue compresses the bladder.

Other important radiological appearance in urogenital system:

  • Fir tree/pine tree/Christmas tree bladder: Neurogenic bladder
  • Sun-burst appearance of the bladder: Extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • Thimble bladder: Tubercular cystitis
  • Paint-brush appearance: Medullary sponge kidney
  • Drooping flower appearance: Ectopic ureter
  • Rim sign/crescent sign: Hydronephrosis
  • Bilateral spider leg deformity: Polycystic kidney disease.
  • Flower vase curves of the ureter: Horseshoe kidney.
  • Saw-toothed or cock screw appearance of ureter: Tubercular ureteritis

questions.text: Following IVP imaging is diagnostic of _____
questions.solution:
• Intravenous pyelogram shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. There is also dilated contrast filled tubules within the renal medulla that is known as paintbrush appearance. These findings are characteristic for medullary sponge kidney (MSK) on intravenous pyelogram.
  • The medullary sponge kidney represents a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as "A" in the CT scan of thorax shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as "A" in the CT Thorax is the Superior Vena Cava.

questions.text: In which condition  is the X ray given below seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows folds that run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen, which is called a feline esophagus and is seen in reflux esophagitis. 

Feline oesophagus is also known as oesophageal shiver, refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower oesophagus on a double contrast barium swallow. The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux and is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae with resultant shortening of the oesophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

Radiologic features: The folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic oesophagus.

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic oesophagitis (wherein the folds will be permanent and be associated with strictures).

 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as MPS 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Other options:

Gaucher disease:

  • rare genetic disorder characterized by the deposition of glucocerebroside in cells of the macrophage-monocyte system.
  • results from the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false?

choices.text: Radiational dose is inversely proportional to the square root of the distance from the source
Ionizing rays do not affect the rapidly dividing cells
Small arteries are resistant to radiation
Bowel is the most radiosensitive in the abdomen

questions.solution:
Ionizing rays affect the rapidly dividing cells.

The particular nature and energy of emissions are characteristic of each radionuclide. The radiation generally is ionizing, meaning that it is highly energetic and damaging to living tissue.

Other options are true:

Option a: Radiation from a point source is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. Tissues twice as far away receive only one-quarter of the dose in the same time period.

Option c: Small arteries are resistant to radiation.

Option d: Bowel is the most radiosensitive in the abdomen.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution or ressortment of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.

  • Repair: As evidenced by cellular recovery during the few hours after exposure.
  • Reassortment: Cell-cycle progression effects. Cells that survive the first dose of radiation will tend to be in a resistant phase of the cell cycle, and within a few hours, they may progress into a more radiosensitive phase.
  • Repopulation: During a 4- to 6-week course of radiotherapy, tumour cells that survive irradiation may proliferate and thus increase the number of cells which must be killed.
  • Reoxygenation: In a tumour, the radioresistant hypoxic cells will selectively survive after a dose fraction, but thereafter, when their oxygen supply improves, their radiosensitivity will increase.
  • Radiosensitivity: For a given fractionation course (or for single-dose irradiation), the haemopoietic system shows a greater response than the kidney, even allowing for the different timing of the response. Similarly, some tumours are more radioresponsive than others to a particular fractionation schedule, and this is largely due to differences in radiosensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are indications for radiotherapy in carcinoma breast?
questions.solution:
Indications for Radiotherapy in Carcinoma Breast:

  • Breast-conserving surgery.
  • Post mastectomy RT in patients with large tumors, large number of positive lymph nodes, extensive lymphovascular invasion.
  • Neo-adjuvant in stage 3A and stage 3B breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is not used for brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for systemic radiotherapy.

I-125 is used for brachytherapy.

Note: Cobalt-60 is used in High-Dose Rate (HDR) Brachytherapy. It is the well established and clinically proven isotope for all HDR brachytherapy treatments.

questions.text: A young boy was hit by a cricket ball on his left eye. There was no restriction in ocular movements nor any visual disturbances. However, the ophthalmologist wanted to check for a foreign body. He used the instrument shown below. What is the false statement regarding this?

choices.text: It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle
It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber
It is used for the localization of a foreign body

questions.solution:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope of four-mirror type, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber and not the posterior chamber. 

Types:

  • Indirect gonioprism: provides a mirror image of the opposite angle.
  • Direct goniolens: provides a direct view of the angle

Application:

  • To view the angle of the anterior chamber
  • Localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumours in the angle
  • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
  • Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of double vision. On examination, it is noticed that the patient’s right eye is capable of abduction but not adduction. There is horizontal nystagmus in the right eye. The left eye however is not capable of either abduction or adduction. Where would you expect the brain lesion to be present?
questions.solution:
The given description is that of One and a half syndrome. Left PPRF and Left MLF lesion are both involved in this condition.


The pathologic lesion is in the left dorsal pontine tegmentum which involves both ipsilateral PPRF (or the abducens nucleus) and the ipsilateral Median longitudinal fasciculus. This causes the paralysis of abduction and adduction on the left side, and only paralysis of adduction on the right.

Horizontal gaze

  • It involves 2 muscles: ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus.
  • The center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).
  • From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus.
  • Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus.

In the left One and a half syndrome, Due to the PPRF lesion, the horizontal gaze of the left eye is lost (Left lateral rectus and right medial rectus). Left medial rectus adduction is lost due to the lesion in left MLF and there is abduction nystagmus in the right eye.

 

Image: The Horizontal gaze pathway

Lesions in this pathway

  • Horizontal gaze palsy: Due to lesion in the PPRF of the same side
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
  • One and a half syndrome: Caused by lesions in both MLF and PPRF of the same side.

Vertical gaze palsy

Center is located in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the dorsal midbrain (riMLF).

The important types of vertical gaze palsy are as follows:

  • Parinaud's syndrome: Upgaze palsy
  • Steel–Richardsons syndrome: Downgaze palsy

questions.text: An old woman underwent a cataract surgery one year back. Now she is complaining of blurring of vision in that operated eye for the past one month. It was gradual in onset and not associated with pain, redness, or watering. However, her vision was clear post-surgery one year back. What is the most common cause of the deterioration of the vision?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is typical of posterior capsular opacification, which is a late complication of cataract surgery.

Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows the extracapsular extraction of the lens. In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ. In many cases these remnants are fine, forming a thin membrane, which is difficult to see. In other cases, especially when the cataract was not mature, some soft, clear cortex sticks to the capsule.

The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: Which of the following bulges out in keratocele?
questions.solution:
In keratocele, the layer that bulges out is the Descemet’s membrane. Hence, it’s also called Descemetocele. It happens when the overlying layers are eroded by inflammatory processes secondary to infection. The Descemet’s membrane is resistant to inflammation and bulges out due to the intra-ocular pressure.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture.

questions.text: Identify the marked finding in a patient who underwent cataract surgery:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Soemmering’s ring. It is defined as a thick ring of after cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction. No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear.

If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

Other options:

Vossius ring – Formed after blunt trauma as a circular brown ring on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule.

Weiss or Vogt’s ring – It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Fleischer’s ring – It refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

questions.text: The image given below depicts a skin manifestation of a neurocutaneous disorder. Which of the following conditions given below are not associated with this neurocutaneous disorder?
questions.solution:
The image shows the shagreen patch seen in tuberous sclerosis. Out of the given options, Lisch nodules is not associated with tuberous sclerosis. Lisch nodules are associated with neurofibromatosis.

Clinical features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • CNS involvement (hallmark of tuberous sclerosis)
    • Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles where they undergo calcification
    • These benign subependymal nodules lesions can grow into subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA)
    • The characteristic brain lesion is a cortical tuber (white matter lesion)
  • Skin
    • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Periungual fibroma
    • Shagreen patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
  • Others
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma

Facial angiofibromas (Adenoma sebaceum)

Periungual fibroma:

Confetti skin lesions:

questions.text: A one-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discolouration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The emergency depicted is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases the peripheral resistance.

Children with congenital cyanotic heart disease are prone to develop cyanotic spells. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking an agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/panic/irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity
    (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options in this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position.
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate (for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis)
  • IV phenylephrine (as it increases the systemic vascular resistance)
  • IV propranolol (as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF)
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child is required to break the spell.

Note:- Paroxysmal Hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as Tet spells/ Blue spells/ Hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of fallout, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF appears clear, with reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased lymphocytes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased lymphocytes levels is a typical presentation of tubercular meningitis.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Chloride Low Very low Normal
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

Tubercular meningitis

  • Common between 6 months and 4 years of age
  • Usually spread by hematogenous route
  • Gelatinous exudate infiltrates corticomeningeal blood vessels leading to hydrocephalus.
  • Three stages
    • Prodromal stage
    • stage of meningitis
    • stage of coma
  • CSF study shows reduced sugar level, increased protein level, and lymphocytosis.
  • Treatment includes antitubercular drugs for 12 months and corticosteroids (to reduce neurologic sequelae).

questions.text: The gross motor milestone attained by the child shown in the below image will correspond to the age of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a child standing with support. This motor milestone is attained at around 9-10 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding secondary lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Breast milk should not be stopped in secondary lactose intolerance.

Secondary lactose intolerance follows small bowel mucosal damage (celiac disease, rotavirus infection) and is usually transient, improving with mucosal healing.

Lactase deficiency can be diagnosed by H2-breath test or by measurement of lactase activity in mucosal tissue retrieved by small bowel biopsy. Diagnostic testing is not mandatory, and often simple dietary changes that reduce or eliminate lactose from the diet relieve symptoms, so breast milk is not stopped in secondary lactose intolerence.

questions.text: A baby born to an HIV positive mother was brought to the clinic. You suspect the baby to be infected too. Which of the following clinical features may suggest stage 1 HIV in this patient?
questions.solution:
Persistent lymphadenopathy is seen in stage 1 of AIDS in children

Presentations of clinical-stage 1 of AIDS include the following:

  • The child may be asymptomatic.
  • Persistent lymphadenopathy may be observed.

Other options:

  • Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections occur in stage 2
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea and fever occur in stage 3

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema
  • Herpes zoster
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Stage 3

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Lymph node TB
  • Pulmonary TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Stage 4

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)
  • Chronic Herpes Simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi Sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder.

VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF).

VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation.

Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 1 disease. 

Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (Type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor Absence Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Adhesion defect: Platelets cannot adhere to subendothelium because of the lack of receptors (Gp Ib-IX-V) for VWF, which mediates platelet adhesion.

 

 Aggregation defect: Platelets cannot aggregate because of lack of receptors (Gp IIb/IIIa) for fibrinogen that form the bridges between platelets during aggregation.

 1. Platelet adhesion defect: Normally VWF binds to platelet GPIB-IX receptor and collagen in the subendothelium

2. Factor VIII deficiency- Normally VWF binds to factor VIII in circulation and prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild Thrombocytopenia  Normal  Normal (Except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)
Platelet morphology Large platelets/ megathrombocytes with dense granules Normal  Normal/ large
Bleeding time

Prolonged

Platelet aggregation tests (collagen, ADP, thrombin) Normal Abnormal  Normal

 Abnormal (platelets does not aggregate)

Does not normalize after addition of normal serum

questions.text: The chromosomal abnormality associated in a neonate with prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is most probably _________
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edwards syndrome, i.e., Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

Other options:

Trisomy 13 (Patau’s syndrome):

  • It is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities.
  • Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent.
  • The midline facial abnormalities that are seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”).
  • Other defects associated with Patau’s syndrome include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases.

Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome):

  • It is the most common chromosomal abnormality.
  • Children with Down’s syndrome have severe mental retardation, which progressively declines with advancing age.
  • Patients have characteristic facial features that include a flat facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds,
  • There is a horizontal palmar crease, and muscle tone at birth is decreased that leads to a “floppy baby.

questions.text: False negative normal APGAR score is seen in  __________.
questions.solution:
False-negative normal APGAR score is seen in maternal acidosis.

False-negative APGAR, i.e., normal Apgar score with fetal acidosis is seen in

  • Maternal acidosis
  • High fetal catecholamine levels
  • Some full-term infants

False-positive APGAR, i.e., no fetal acidosis but low Apgar score is seen in:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs - analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulphate
  • Acute cerebral edema
  • Spinal cord trauma
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Choanal atresia
  • Congenital pneumonia and sepsis
  • Congenital myopathy/neuropathy
  • Hemorrhage/hypovolemia

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: The inheritance pattern shown below is:
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.

questions.text: The false statement regarding the method shown in the image below is _____.

choices.text: It is a part of warm chain
It can be done by fathers also
Can not be carried out by hemodynamically unstable mothers

questions.solution:
The image shows kangaroo mother care. It can be carried out by hemodynamically unstable mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators.

Kangaroo mother care is part of warm chain transportation of babies, especially when incubator ambulances are not available for transportation of the baby.

Kangaroo discharge: early discharge from hospital has been shown to cause reduced rates of hospital-acquired infections.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: The most common manifestation that you would expect in a child infected by E. histolytica is:
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic cyst passage is the most common manifestation of E. histolytica.

 

Amebiasis:

  • Caused by Entamoeba histolytica
  • Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasion and destruction.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6–8/day).
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. Some may have only intermittent diarrhea alternating with constipation.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers. 
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • It occurs in <1% of infected individuals.
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess.
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography, computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the brisk Moro reflex seen?
questions.solution:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. 

In hypoglycemic babies, there is activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex which is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backwards onto the examiner’s hand.

An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities.

 The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

Other options:

  • In stage III hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), the muscles are flaccid and the infant is in a comatose state. So, Moro reflex is absent.
  • Kernicterus is characterized by the deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. So, Moro reflex is absent.
  • Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, Moro reflex is absent on the side of injury since the nerve supplying the muscles is affected.

 Moro reflex in different stages of Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

  • Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk
  • Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete
  • Stage III HIE (severe): Absent

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in function of neutrophils that includes adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of cord, which is usually associated with infection of cord stump.

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: A 15-year old patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following presenting features would categorize him to be in the 'A' category of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Hodgkin's lymphoma is classified into A and B categories, A is used to identify asymptomatic patients and B is for patients who exhibit any B symptoms. 

B symptoms

  • The presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive days
  • Drenching night sweats
  • Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 months 

Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma:

Stage I

Involvement of a single lymph node (I) or of a single extra-lymphatic organ or site (IE)

Stage II

Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site and 1 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE)

Stage III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which may be accompanied by

involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or

by localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site (IIIE) or

both (IIISE)

Stage IV

Diffuse or disseminated involvement of 1 or more

extra-lymphatic organs or tissues with or without

associated lymph node involvement

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early complication of fracture?
questions.solution:
Complex regional pain syndrome -CRPS(earlier known as Reflex sympathetic dystrophy or Sudeck's dystrophy or algodystrophy) is a late complication of fracture. Rest options are early complications

CRPS is divided into 2 types. CRPS type 1 occurs after trivial trauma or fracture and is explained below.

It occurs as a sequela of trauma and presents as a swollen, tender, and painful condition. It progressively undergoes atrophy of skin, muscle, and even nail over weeks resulting in fixed deformity at last. X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better.  Long term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

CRPS type 2 is related to causalgia after nerve injury.

Other options:

Fat embolism syndrome-Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress,neurological abnormalities and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male motorcyclist presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with significant left hip pain and inability to bear weight. The affected leg is in the position as shown in the below image. Which among the following nerves is most commonly injured in a case like this?

choices.text: Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.solution:
In the above image, the affected leg is in the state of flexion, abduction, and external rotation (FABER). Hence the most likely diagnosis is anterior dislocation of the hip and the most common nerve injured is femoral nerve.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as superior and inferior. When seen from the side:

  • If the femoral head lies anteriorly it is called as the superior (pubic) type
  • If the femoral head lies in the groin it is called as the inferior (obturator) type

questions.text: The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up due to:

choices.text: Force of gravity on ipsilateral arm

questions.solution:
The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up by the action of the sternocleidomastoid.

The lateral fragment in a clavicle fracture is displaced inferiorly due to gravity acting on the ipsilateral arm.

Fracture of the clavicle:

Mechanism of injury:

  • Fall on the point of the shoulder
  • Direct trauma over the clavicle due to road traffic accident
  • Fall on the outstretched hand

The fracture occurs most commonly at the junction of the middle third and outer third of the clavicle

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment
    • Cuff and collar sling
    • Strapping and sling suspension
    • Figure of 8 bandaging
  • Operative treatment (for open fracture, injury to the neurovascular bundle, non union, floating shoulder etc)
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

questions.text: Identify the tumour that is correctly matched with its primary location:
questions.solution:

  • Enchondroma/chondroma- benign tumor arising from islands of cartilage in the metaphyses of bones formed by endochondral ossification.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Asperger's syndrome?

choices.text: More common in boys than girls
Onset is after the age of 3

questions.solution:
Patients with Asperger's syndrome have no delay in language development.

Asperger's syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterized by a wide range of impairment in social communications and restricted and repetitive behaviors.

Features of Asperger's disorder:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level.
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behavior.
  • No significant delay in language.
  • Do not manifest with mental retardation.

According to DSM-IV-TR, individuals with Asperger's disorder exhibit no language delay, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with mood lability, sadness, and tearfulness 5 days after delivery. She has no thoughts of harming the baby. There is no history of previous mood disorders. There is no family history of mood disorders. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postpartum blues and the preferred treatment is supportive therapy.

Mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolve spontaneously are characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness. These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If the symptoms persist longer than two weeks, evaluation is indicated for postpartum depression.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

30-75%

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. 3 days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofaciolingual movements. This effect is due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from acute dystonia. Acute dystonia is seen due to the D2(Dopamine receptor) blocking effect of the antipsychotic.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake.It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back.

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha blockade results in hypotension and sedation.
Option B: H1 blockade results in an antiemetic effect and causes sedation
Option C: Antimuscarinic effect result in dry mouth, dilated pupils, and urinary retention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male prefers to be detached, does not mingle with people, and often remains alone. He does not experience pleasure and is rather preoccupied with himself and his own fantasy world. This personality type will show__________
questions.solution:
A young male who is a loner by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality. Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking.

Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

High novelty seeking:

  • Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.
  • High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.
  • Cluster B personality disorders like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

Low novelty seeking:

  • Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.
  • Individual with schizoid personality is a markedly detached person who stays alone in introspection and lives in his own world of fantasy. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

Other options:

  • Magical thinking – Schizotypal personality
  • Grandiosity - Narcissistic personality
  • Impulsivity – Borderline personality, Antisocial personality

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. Eg: Suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity, with accompanying jealousy.

DELUSIONAL MISIDENTIFICATION SYNDROMES

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli’s syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppleganger syndrome: A person feels he has his own impostor(duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: The circuit seen in the given image is a modification of:
questions.solution:
The device shown in the given image is Bain circuit, which is a coaxial version of Mapleson class D.

The Bain circuit has the following features

  • It has incorporated the fresh gas tubing inside the corrugated breathing tube to supply gases near the mask.
  • The APL valve is located near the reservoir bag.

The Bain circuit differs from the Mapleson D as it has the fresh gas flow through a separate tubing within the transparent corrugated tube. Hence the Bain circuit is called the co-axial modification of Mapleson D circuit.

Advantages:

  • It is efficient in controlled ventilation since fresh gas flow forces alveolar air away from the patient and towards the APL valve.
  • Since the fresh gas tubing is inside the breathing tube, the bulk of the circuit is reduced and the fresh gas within the tube retains heat and humidity as it comes in contact with the warmer expired gases.

Disadvantage:

There is a possibility of kinking of the fresh gas inlet tubing. Hence, periodic inspection of the inner tubing is mandatory to prevent this complication.

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida has come with labor pain. On examination, she has effective uterine contractions with cervical dilation of 4 cm. In view of pain, she has requested the obstetrician for a painless, safe labor. If the anesthetist plans to give epidural for the same, which of the following would be preferred?
questions.solution:
A combination of a local anesthetic agent, ropivacaine with an opioid, sufentanil would be preferred.

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by the combination of local anesthetics with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Moreover, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

Concentrations used for epidural:

Drug Concentrations
  Without opioid With opioid
Bupivacaine 0.25% 0.0625-0.125%
Ropivacaine 0.2% 0.0625-0.2%

The dose of opioid used:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

Other options:

 A combination of 1.5% lidocaine with 1: 200,000 epinephrine can be used as a test dose before giving the epidural drug mixture.

Epidural opioids, like morphine, can produce satisfactory labor analgesia only at relatively larger doses (>7.5 mg), which can cause respiratory depression. Hence it is not preferred.

When compared with ropivacaine + sufentanil, bupivacaine used alone is less preferred.

questions.text: Inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax is ______
questions.solution:
Inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air containing cavities as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • N2O although insoluble when compared to volatile agents, it is about 35 times more soluble than O2 and N2 
  • Rapid uptake of nitrous oxide diminishes the volume to the alveolus
  • This 'concentrates' the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus

Second gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction

Diffusion hypoxia

  • aka Fink's effect
  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia.
  • Avoided by administering 100% oxygen for about 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous in gas-filled spaces

  • N2O diffuses into a gas-filled cavity more rapidly than the air (principally nitrogen) diffuses out
  • This increases the pressure within the cavity if the volume of the cavity is rigid.
  • Hence N2O is contraindicated in:
    • Venous or arterial air embolism
    • Acute intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
    • Pulmonary air cysts
    • Intraocular air bubbles
    • Tympanic membrane grafting

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent

questions.text: A 20-year-old primi in her second trimester of pregnancy is posted for the open appendectomy. The ideal anesthetic technique for this surgery is _______
questions.solution:
Spinal anesthesia is preferred over other techniques for the appendectomy in the second trimester. Total anesthetic drug exposure is least with spinal anesthesia over others.

General anesthesia is associated with a greater risk of:

  • Pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents
  • Difficult or failed intubation
  • Drug exposure to the fetus

Epidural anesthesia has the risk of

  • Accidental intravascular injection
  • Accidental intrathecal injection

Although spinal anesthesia is preferred in most situations, the choice between general anesthesia and spinal anesthesia is to be individualized. In general, spinal anesthesia is appropriate for open appendectomies and general anesthesia for laparoscopic appendectomies.

Caudal anesthesia:

Caudal anesthesia involves deposition of local anesthesia in the caudal epidural space, accessed through the sacral hiatus.

Related Pearl: Regional Anesthesia in Obstetrics

  • Pregnant patients display enhanced sensitivity to LA during regional anesthesia because of hormonal factors and engorgement of epidural venous plexus resulting in decreased epidural space and subarachnoid space (CSF volume).This enhances the cephalad spread of LA solution during spinal and epidural anesthesia.
  • Lower doses of LA agents and pain relief drugs are used because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics during parturition as a result of hormonal and cardiovascular effects.
  • Lignocaine is less protein bound and nerves are more sensitive to LA agents.
  • NOT a cause of decreased anesthetic requirement during pregnancy Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • The level of the block under spinal anesthesia is desirable upto T4.
  • Lumbar epidural - The most preferred technique for painless labor.

questions.text: A person is having opioid-induced bradycardia. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium is vagolytic (resulting from blockade of M2 receptors) leading to increased heart rate and hence can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia.

Pancuronium-induced tachycardia has been attributed to the following:

  • Vagolytic action: Inhibition of M2 receptors
  • Sympathetic stimulation: Direct by blockade of neuronal uptake of norepinephrine and indirectly by release of norepinephrine from adrenergic nerve endings.

Other options: Vecuronium, cisatracurium, and atracurium are nonvagolytic relaxants

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium

questions.text: According to the FIGO classification, tumor of the ovary involving the fallopian tube but not extending to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissue is classified under what stage?
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumor involving the fallopian tube comes under stage IIA according to the FIGO classification.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage 1:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C:
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage 2:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B:Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
       
  • Stage 3:
    • A
      • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
      • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
       
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: Which of the following micro-organisms is most commonly associated with the finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows violin-string adhesions associated with chlamydial infections. It is also seen frequently with gonorrheal infections.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome refers to inflammation of the liver capsule with adhesion formation. This is due to perihepatitis in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by gonococcal and chlamydial infection. It results in violin-string adhesions between the liver and the diaphragm or liver and anterior abdominal wall. The condition is characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The diagnosis can be made through laparoscopy or laparotomy via direct visualization of violin string-like adhesions.

questions.text: Which of the following gestational period qualifies to be called a post-term pregnancy according to ACOG guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the ACOG guidelines, a post-term pregnancy is defined as one reaching to or extending beyond 42 0/7 weeks (42 completed weeks) of gestation.

The guidelines label the pregnancy according to the gestational age as follows:

Preterm pregnancy: Less than 37 0/7 weeks

Early term pregnancy: 37 0/7 weeks to 38 6/7 weeks

Full-term pregnancy: 39 0/7 weeks to 40 6/7 weeks

Late-term pregnancy: 41 0/7 weeks to 41 6/7 weeks

Post-term pregnancy: 42 0/7 weeks or higher

questions.text: A mother presents with fever and right-sided breast pain in the puerperal period. Examination reveals diffuse tenderness and erythema of the right breast without any localized firmness or fluctuance. How is this condition managed?

choices.text: Cessation of breast feeding on the affected side

questions.solution:
The history and findings suggest a diagnosis of lactational mastitis which is managed with antibiotics. Beta-lactamase resistant penicillins such as cloxacillin, dicloxacillin or flucloxacillin are given. If resistant staphylococcal infection is prevalent and suspected, vancomycin, clindamycin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be given.

Lactational mastitis:

The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Symptoms appear in 3rd/4th week
  • Infection is almost always unilateral
  • The immediate source of organism that causes mastitis is always the infant's nose and throat (Not GIT).
  • Predisposing factors: fissures/abrasions/cracks in nipple

Other options:

  • Breast feeding is to be continued as it poses no risk to the infant. It also helps avoid deleterious effects such as painful breast engorgement and breast abscess.
  • Incision and drainage is done only if breast abscess is present.

questions.text: Which of the following is termed as a compound presentation?

choices.text: Passage of fetal head and thorax through pelvic cavity at the same time
Presentation of one breech and one head in twin pregnancies
Presentation of an arm alongside the fetal head
Impaction of shoulder in shoulder presentation

questions.solution:
Compound presentation is defined as an extremity prolapsing alongside the presenting part. Contracted pelvis, fetal prematurity, polyhydramnios, and multi-fetal gestations predispose to this presentation.

The most common compound presentation is a hand prolapsing alongside the head. In most cases, expectant management is enough. With the progression of labor, the prolapsed hand retracts with the descent of the fetal head. If retraction fails and the hand seems to be blocking the head, the prolapsed arm is gently pushed upward and fundal pressure is applied to promote descent of the head.

If cord prolapse is present or the pelvis is contracted, Caesarean section should be done.

questions.text: All are true about first trimester abortion except__

choices.text: Mifepristone 200 mg oral given on day 1
Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks
Medical outpatient abortion is effective upto 9 weeks

questions.solution:
Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal suppository is given for second trimester abortion and not first trimester abortion.

Dinoprostone gel (PGE2 analog) was used for cervical ripening and resulted in a shorter induction abortion interval which is much beneficial in seconfd trimester than the first trimester. Also, it is quite expensive and needs refrigeration.

Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of PGE1 being much cheaper, safe and capable of being easily stored at room temperature has been tried by both oral and vaginal routes.

Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks. For suction abortion done at <6 weeks gestation, a distinct drawback is that the pregnancy may be small and missed by the curette. To identiy placenta, the aspirated contents are rinsed in a strainer to remove blood, and then placed in a clear plastic container with saline and examined with back lighting. Placental tissue macroscopically appears soft, fluffy, and feathery.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9weeks)

First trimester 

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol

Misoprostol only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually or buccally.

Methotrexate/Misoprostol

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given

 
Second Trimester

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended) : 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone

20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated Oxytocin

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline

questions.text: The sign seen in the following sonography is suggestive of which fetal anomaly__
questions.solution:
The lemon sign is suggestive of spina bifida.

This is called lemon sign as at the level of lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by arrow). It is alsocharectaristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

Another sign called banana sign can also be seen in spina bifida in which at the level of posterior fossa, anterior curvature of cerebellum with effacement of cisterna magna can be seen.

Related Pearl: Signs in obstetrics: Radiological signs

Radiological signs:

  • Bagel sign:Ultrasonographic sign. Gestational sac in the adnexa with hyperechoic ring.
  • Ball Sign:Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death. X-ray shows crumpled up spine of the fetus.
  • Banana Sign:Ultrasound sign in open spina bifida. Shows abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum. Due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation
  • Double Bubble Sign:Useful in prenatal diagnosis of duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia usuallypresents with polyhydramnios and produces dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum.
  • Double decidual sac Sign:Normal Ultrasonographic appearance of intrauterine gestational sac. Seen as twoconcentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space
  • Lambda Sign:Ultrasonographic sign seen in dichorionic pregnancies. Due to the chorionic tissuein between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
  • Lemon Sign:Ultrasound sign showing inward scalloping of the frontal bones of the calvarium such that the head appears shaped like a lemon. Seen in spina bifida with associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
  • Robert’s Sign:Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death. X-ray shows presence of gas in thefetal great vessels. Earliest radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death
  • Spalding Sign:Sign of intrauterine fetal death. Overlapping of skull bones after fetal demise.Observed by ultrasonogrm.
  • Stuck Twin Sign:Seen in twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Due to the severe oligohydramniossmaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall. This is called stuck twinsign.
  • ‘T’ Sign:Ultrasonographic sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman who desires future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman on USG shows a unilocular cyst in the ovary of 5 cm with negative serology. Treatment involves:
questions.solution:
Follow up after 1-2 cycles of oral combined pills (conservative management) is the best treatment modality in the given scenario as it is most likely to be a functional cyst.

For conservative management of ovarian cysts, the following criteria should usually be met:

  • Asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Unilateral
  • No solid areas
  • Normal CA 125
  • Less than 7cm
  • Ultrasound re-examination after 3-6 months (no signs of increase in size or malignancy)

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal disorders
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Usually 6-8cm in diameter
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless haemorrhage occurs
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which they arise
  • Spontaneous regression occurs within 4-6 months

Treatment of functional cysts:

  • Usually conservative; spontaneous regression occurs after 4-6months.
  • Oral combined pills to hasten the regression of cyst.
  • Laparotomy for tumours more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 24 year old primi had delivered monochorionic monoamniotic twins. For these twins to be born, the division should occur on/after __________
questions.solution:
For monochorionic monoamniotic twins to be born, the division should occur after 8 days.

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A 24 year old multipara presented to the labour ward in severe pre-eclampsia. Magnesium sulphate is started as a prophylactic measure. In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if ___________.

choices.text: Urine output <100 ml in last 4 hours

questions.solution:
In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if Patellar reflex is brisk.

Magnesium sulfate is used for management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The two regimens commonly used are tabulated below.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 min followed by 10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock) 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4–6 g IV slow over 15–20 minute 1–2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity. Repeated IM injections of Magnesium sulfate are continued only if:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine is > 1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach
  • It blocks neuronal Calcium influx
  • Reduced presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate
  • Blockade of glutaminergic NMDA receptors
  • Potentiation of adenosine action

Note: MgSO4 does not control hypertension

questions.text: Diagnostic criteria for primary abdominal pregnancy is__
questions.solution:
The criteria laid down by Studdiford is used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy.

Site of pregnancy Criteria Management
Primary abdominal pregnancy

Studdiford's criteria

  • Both the tubes and ovaries should be normal
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula
  • Pregnancy must be exclusively related to the peritoneal surface 
 Surgical management
Ovarian pregnancy

Spiegelberg's criteria

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • Gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall
 Surgical management
Cervical pregnancy

Rubin's criteria (Palmatic's criteria)

  • The uterus is smaller than surrounding distended cervix
  • Internal os is not dilated
  • Curettage of the endometrial cavity is nonproductive of placental tissue
  • External os opens earlier than in spontaneous abortion
  • Medical management if vitals are stable
  • Surgical management if vitals are unstable

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and normal external genitalia. She has swelling in the right inguinal region. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in complete androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea → Due to the absence of a uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts → Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region → Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, caused by loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Female type external genitalia → In the absence of testosterone's action on genitalia, the genital tubercle enlarges to form the clitoris.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix → Due to the production of Mullerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis.
  • And finally, the XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Other options:

Option A: Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH).

Option C:  21-hydroxylase deficiency causes Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia with virilization in females and ambiguous genitalia. It leads to low cortisol and aldosterone levels, resulting in hypotension and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition found in both males and females. It is associated with low IQ, delayed puberty, low fertility, pulmonary stenosis and HOCM.
