questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 7 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital for the first time in active labour and was found to be HIV positive. She had not taken any drugs for the same. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum duration for which nevirapine is given to the infant if breastfeeding is practised?
questions.solution: Nevirapine prophylaxis has to be given for a minimum period of 12 weeks, as the mother has not taken ART in the antenatal period and the infant is to be breastfed.

questions.text: Identify the grade of perineal tear.
questions.solution:
The picture shows that the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles and more than 50% of external anal sphincter are torn. This happens in grade 3b perineal tear.

questions.text: A 22 year old primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation came to the Opd for regular prenatal visit. Thyroid function test was found to be normal. Which of the following statements is false regarding thyroid in pregnancy?

choices.text: Thyroid binding globulin levels peak at 12 weeks of gestational age
Mild increase in free T4 levels occur transiently during the early weeks of gestation
Thyroid releasing hormone crosses the placenta and stimulates fetal pituitary
Thyroid gland undergoes moderate enlargement during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Thyroid binding globulin (TBG) levels peak at 20 weeks of gestation and then plateau till term.  

Thyroid and pregnancy:         

  • Pregnancy is a state of increased physiological demand. To meet the metabolic needs of the mother and fetus, the thyroid gland undergoes moderate enlargement with glandular hyperplasia and increased vascularity.
  • Thyroid releasing hormone (TRH) crosses the placenta and leads to the release of TSH from fetal pituitary.

questions.text: A 30 year old multigravida at 35 weeks of gestation came to the Opd for regular checkup. In this patient, which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole that is cephalic or podalic-occupies with the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the fetal orientation. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities. By noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly, fetal orientation can be determined.
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip/1st pelvic grip): It assesses the presenting part. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (2nd pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A 45-year-old multifarious woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women > 40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass with free adnexa and myometrial cysts on MRI, all point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis (Endometritis interna):

Adenomyosis is ingrowth of endometrium ( stromal and glandular components ) directly into the myometrium.

Etiology: Vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or excess of estrogen

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous females >40 years
  • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia
  • Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus ( corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy )
  • Bimanual examination: Halbans sign: Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage

Management of adenomyosis 

  • Total Hysterectomy ( Treatment of choice )
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women.

questions.text: The following hysterosalpingogram indicates
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography provides an excellent alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

The above image is a hysteroscopic image of intrauterine adhesions found with Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
The microscopic finding is epithelial cells, with bacteria attached to them called as clue cells.

Clue cells are the most reliable indicators of Bacterial Vaginosis. These vaginal epithelial cells contain many attached bacteria, which create a poorly defined stippled border. At least 20 percent of the epithelial cells should be clue cells in a Wet Mount preparation to be diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis. The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the placental separation method shown in the image below:

choices.text: It is commonly known as Mathews-Duncan method
Occurs during fourth stage of labor
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

  • The separation begins at the centre of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clot.
  • Bleeding does not occur until the placenta is completely extruded.

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the peripheral edge of the placenta. Hence, the maternal surface appears first.
  • The blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall, and escapes out from the vagina. There is no formation of retroplacental clot and the bleeding is profuse in this method of placental separation.
  • It is much less common than Schultze method.

questions.text: Peg cells are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tube.

A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells.

questions.text: This is a picture of the female vulva. What is the homologous male structure marked X?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the image is labia minora. The ventral aspect of the penis (penile urethra) is a male homologue of female labia minora.

The vulva includes mons veneris, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, vestibule, and perineum.

The vulva is the collective name for external genitalia and perineum.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husband is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization. Which of the following is false about anti D immunoprophylaxis?

choices.text: The half life of anti D is 60 days
Can be administered IM or IV depending on the preparation
Second dose is given within 72 hrs of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive
300 microgram of Anti D can neutralise 15 ml of fetal RBCs

questions.solution:
The half-life of anti D is 16 -24 days.

This is the reason why it is given in both third trimester and following delivery. 

Other options:

  • Anti D is given to an unsensitized mother at 28 weeks and then again postpartum.  The dose given postpartum has to be given within 72 hrs of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive.
  • 300 microgram of Anti D can neutralise 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30ml of fetal whole blood. If the volume of fetomaternal haemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of Rh-immune globulin calculated is 10 μg for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is a caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

The WHO partograph is a graphic record of the progress of labor and relevant details of the mother and fetus. It is a repeatedly tested topic in the NBE and Central Institute exams.

questions.text: Best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus is  _____
questions.solution:
Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV US) is the best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus. It is recommended as the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour, so it cannot distinguish between fusion (didelphys and bicornuate) and reabsorption (septate and arcuate) uterine anomalies.

Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV US is not possible, like virgins.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.
